TCQ feature requests?
we have a presentation coming up later!
@yulia:mozilla.org objecting to what?
objecting to the dual view
integration path 2
if I want none of these options, does that count?
that also counts, but could you talk a bit about why?
esp. why not option 1 in that case
it's more exceptional than not, there's already too much irregularity that needs to be dealt with in the language
also I would like to hear from multiple implementations (or other constituents) that this would be useful
@shuyuguo:matrix.org expressed in the editor call, where we talked about this at some length, that he didn't think V8 would find this useful
content.formatted_body: @shu expressed in the editor call, where we talked about this at some length, that he didn't think V8 would find this useful

content.body: I don't want to speak further for him though
@tabatkins:matrix.org this is almost certainly going to be the case, I don't see why it would not be
content.formatted_body: @TabAtkins this is almost certainly going to be the case, I don't see why it would not be

content.body: what I mean is, any IDL is going to be *full* of exceptional cases because it's describing a language that is full of exceptional cases
content.formatted_body: what I mean is, any IDL is going to be full of exceptional cases because it's describing a language that is full of exceptional cases

content.body: doesn't webidl's coercion for numeric arguments not match our current consensus for new apis in tc39
@devsnek:matrix.org yes
all new APIs will require attributes to that effect
I feel like people haven't ready arai's document
* I feel like people haven't read arai's document

m.new_content.body: I feel like people haven't read arai's document

content.body: i feel like having a declarative definition of all our stuff would be nice, especially if it reduces function entry/exit boilerplate. but it seems like webidl is a bit msimatched for us...
i haven't read the full document though
this conversation has not convinced me in the direction of WebIDL, if anything it has convinced me that a JS-specific IDL or no IDL would be better
i guess in particular if the primary argument is reusing assumptions/code from existing webidl... all the extended attributes and special cases probably end up making it a moot point
yulia: btw I'd like to help with this project
content.formatted_body: yulia: btw I'd like to help with this project

content.body: that would be brilliant
It could be nice to generate TypeScript `.d.ts` files if TC39 published those, though I don't know if we would always generate them as a source of truth.
content.formatted_body: It could be nice to generate TypeScript .d.ts files if TC39 published those, though I don't know if we would always generate them as a source of truth.

content.body: I do wonder if an IDL for JS could also be used to generate the actual boilerplate of spec text under that dual approach.
* I do wonder if an IDL for JS could also be used to generate the actual boilerplate of spec text under that dual approach.

m.new_content.body: I do wonder if an IDL for JS could also be used to generate the actual boilerplate of spec text under that dual approach.

content.body: typescript types diverge enough from reality that it probably wouldn't make sense
content.formatted_body: typescript types diverge enough from reality that it probably wouldn't make sense

content.body: DOM types are automatically generated from WebIDL
what I mean is, typescript pretends certain complexity doesn't exist because that's how 99% of users use the built-in and it makes things nicer for them
* DOM types in TypeScript are automatically generated from WebIDL

m.new_content.body: DOM types in TypeScript are automatically generated from WebIDL

content.body: I'm not sure I can officially help with the web IDL stuff, but we've been through a number of internal systems for exposing and describing core parts of our system, and I might well look at what we could do that would closely aligned with web IDL and could be automatically translated.
